message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Distributed Adaptive Tracking Control for High-Order Nonlinear Multiagent Systems Over Event-Triggered Communication
Paper Abstract: In this article, we investigate the consensus problem for high-order nonlinear multiagent systems (MASs) with an uncertain leader under event-triggered communication. Compared with the existing consensus results for nonlinear MASs under event-triggered communication, the class of systems considered is more general, while achieving better performance in term of asymptotic tracking. To estimate the unknown parameters of the uncertain leader, distributed intermediate parameter estimators based on event-triggered communication mechanism are first introduced. To guarantee that high-order derivatives exist when applying the backstepping method, such estimators are further modified to obtain final estimators having a polynomial form by using the Hermite interpolation method. Moreover, novel high-order filters are proposed to generate local reference signals and to ensure the existence of high-order derivatives of the filter states. Based on the developed filters, a backstepping-based decentralized adaptive controller is developed. It is proved that consensus errors are asymptotically convergent with the developed method. Finally, simulation examples are provided to show the effectiveness of the proposed method.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Web search results for query: "Multiagent systems"

Links: [{"title":"Multi-agent system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_system"},{"title":"Autonomous Agents and Multi-Agent Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_Agents_and_Multi-Agent_Systems"},{"title":"International Conference on Autonomous Agents and Multiagent Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Conference_on_Autonomous_Agents_and_Multiagent_Systems"},{"title":"Distributed multi-agent reasoning system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_multi-agent_reasoning_system"},{"title":"Agent-oriented software engineering - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agent-oriented_software_engineering"},{"title":"Katia Sycara - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Katia_Sycara"},{"title":"Peter Stone (professor) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peter_Stone_(professor)"},{"title":"Multi-agent reinforcement learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_reinforcement_learning"},{"title":"Multi-agent planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_planning"},{"title":"Wassim Michael Haddad - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wassim_Michael_Haddad"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of multiagent systems:

## Definition

A multi-agent system (MAS) is a computerized system composed of multiple interacting intelligent agents.(no content)Multi-agent systems can solve problems that are difficult or impossible for an individual agent or a monolithic system to solve.

## Key Characteristics

Agents in a multi-agent system have several important characteristics including autonomy (agents are at least partially independent and self-aware), local views (no agent has a full global view), and decentralization (no agent is designated as controlling).(no content)With advancements in large language models (LLMs), LLM-based multi-agent systems have emerged as a new area of research, enabling more sophisticated interactions and coordination among agents.

## Applications

Applications where multi-agent systems research may deliver an appropriate approach include online trading, disaster response, target surveillance and social structure modelling.

## Related Fields

Multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) is a sub-field of reinforcement learning that focuses on studying the behavior of multiple learning agents that coexist in a shared environment.(no content)Agent-oriented software engineering (AOSE) is a software engineering paradigm that arose to apply best practice in the development of complex Multi-Agent Systems (MAS).


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Links: [{"title":"Nonlinear system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonlinear_system"},{"title":"Category:Nonlinear systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Nonlinear_systems"},{"title":"Nonlinear system identification - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonlinear_system_identification"},{"title":"Non-Linear Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Non-Linear_Systems"},{"title":"Nonlinear control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonlinear_control"},{"title":"Linear system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_system"},{"title":"Linear stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_stability"},{"title":"Dynamical systems theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dynamical_systems_theory"},{"title":"Dynamical system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dynamical_system"},{"title":"Limit cycle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Limit_cycle"}]

Here are the search results for "Nonlinear systems":

## Definition

A nonlinear system is defined as any system that is not linear, that is any system that does not satisfy the superposition principle. More specifically, nonlinear systems are systems whose behavior is not expressible as a linear function of its descriptors.

## Key Characteristics

A system of differential equations is said to be nonlinear if it is not a system of linear equations. Problems involving nonlinear differential equations are extremely diverse, and methods of solution or analysis are problem dependent.(no content)One of the greatest difficulties of nonlinear problems is that it is not generally possible to combine known solutions into new solutions. Unlike linear systems that can use the superposition principle, this limitation makes nonlinear systems more challenging to analyze.

## Examples and Applications

Examples of nonlinear differential equations are the Navier–Stokes equations in fluid dynamics and the Lotka–Volterra equations in biology.(no content)Nonlinear control theory applies to more real-world systems, because all real control systems are nonlinear.(no content)Some aspects of the weather are seen to be chaotic, where simple changes in one part of the system produce complex effects throughout. This nonlinearity is one of the reasons why accurate long-term forecasts are impossible with current technology.

## Special Behaviors

Even simple nonlinear dynamical systems often exhibit seemingly random behavior that has been called chaos. The branch of dynamical systems that deals with the clean definition and investigation of chaos is called chaos theory.

Web search results for query: "Hermite interpolation"

Links: [{"title":"Hermite interpolation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hermite_interpolation"},{"title":"Cubic Hermite spline - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cubic_Hermite_spline"},{"title":"Hermite polynomials - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hermite_polynomials"},{"title":"Hermite spline - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hermite_spline"},{"title":"Monotone cubic interpolation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monotone_cubic_interpolation"}]

## Hermite Interpolation

Hermite interpolation, named after Charles Hermite, is a method of polynomial interpolation which generalizes Lagrange interpolation.(no content)In the restricted formulation, Hermite interpolation consists of computing a polynomial of degree as low as possible that matches an unknown function both in observed value and the observed value of its first m derivatives.(no content)This means that n(m + 1) values must be known.

### Key Applications

One common application is the **cubic Hermite spline**. A cubic Hermite spline is a spline where each piece is a third-degree polynomial specified in Hermite form, that is, by its values and first derivatives at the end points of the corresponding domain interval.(no content)Cubic polynomial splines are extensively used in computer graphics and geometric modeling to obtain curves or motion trajectories that pass through specified points of the plane or three-dimensional space.

### Computational Methods

The Hermite interpolation problem is a problem of linear algebra that has the coefficients of the interpolation polynomial as unknown variables and a confluent Vandermonde matrix as its matrix.

Links: [{"title":"Hermite interpolation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hermite_interpolation"},{"title":"Cubic Hermite spline - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cubic_Hermite_spline"},{"title":"Hermite polynomials - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hermite_polynomials"},{"title":"Hermite spline - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hermite_spline"},{"title":"Monotone cubic interpolation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monotone_cubic_interpolation"}]

## Hermite Interpolation

Hermite interpolation, named after Charles Hermite, is a method of polynomial interpolation which generalizes Lagrange interpolation.(no content)In the restricted formulation, Hermite interpolation consists of computing a polynomial of degree as low as possible that matches an unknown function both in observed value and the observed value of its first m derivatives.(no content)This means that n(m + 1) values must be known.

### Key Applications

One common application is the **cubic Hermite spline**. A cubic Hermite spline is a spline where each piece is a third-degree polynomial specified in Hermite form, that is, by its values and first derivatives at the end points of the corresponding domain interval.(no content)Cubic polynomial splines are extensively used in computer graphics and geometric modeling to obtain curves or motion trajectories that pass through specified points of the plane or three-dimensional space.

### Computational Methods

The Hermite interpolation problem is a problem of linear algebra that has the coefficients of the interpolation polynomial as unknown variables and a confluent Vandermonde matrix as its matrix.

Web search results for query: "Adaptive control"

Links: [{"title":"Adaptive control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_control"},{"title":"Adaptive cruise control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_cruise_control"},{"title":"Adaptive collaborative control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_collaborative_control"},{"title":"Self-tuning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self-tuning"},{"title":"Adaptive traffic control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_traffic_control"},{"title":"Continuous monitoring and adaptive control (stormwater management) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Continuous_monitoring_and_adaptive_control_(stormwater_management)"},{"title":"Xbox Adaptive Controller - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xbox_Adaptive_Controller#:~:text=The co-creator of the,much they could be ..."},{"title":"Real-time adaptive security - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Real-time_adaptive_security"},{"title":"File:Xbox Adaptive Controller V&A.JPG - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Xbox_Adaptive_Controller_V&A.JPG"},{"title":"Adaptive autonomy","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_autonomy"}]

Here are the search results for "Adaptive control":

## Overview

Adaptive control is the control method used by a controller which must adapt to a controlled system with parameters which vary, or are initially uncertain.(no content)For example, as an aircraft flies, its mass will slowly decrease as a result of fuel consumption; a control law is needed that adapts itself to such changing conditions.

## Key Differences from Other Control Methods

Adaptive control is different from robust control in that it does not need a priori information about the bounds on these uncertain or time-varying parameters; robust control guarantees that if the changes are within given bounds the control law need not be changed, while adaptive control is concerned with control law changing itself.

## Foundations and Methods

The foundation of adaptive control is parameter estimation, which is a branch of system identification. Common methods of estimation include recursive least squares and gradient descent.(no content)Lyapunov stability is used to derive these update laws and show convergence criteria.

## Types of Adaptive Control

Direct methods are ones wherein the estimated parameters are those directly used in the adaptive controller. In contrast, indirect methods are those in which the estimated parameters are used to calculate required controller parameters. Hybrid methods rely on both estimation of parameters and direct modification of the control law.

## Recent Developments

In recent times, adaptive control has been merged with intelligent techniques such as fuzzy and neural networks to bring forth new concepts such as fuzzy adaptive control.(no content)A particularly successful application of adaptive control has been adaptive flight control. This body of work has focused on guaranteeing stability of a model reference adaptive control scheme using Lyapunov arguments.

Kokotovic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Petar_V._Kokotovic"},{"title":"Talk:Backstepping - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Backstepping"},{"title":"Control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory"},{"title":"Backpropagation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Backpropagation"},{"title":"Backstay - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Backstay"},{"title":"Control reversal - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_reversal"},{"title":"Take back control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Take_Back_Control"},{"title":"Exponential backoff - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Exponential_backoff"}]

Based on the web search results, here's what I found about backstepping control:

## Overview

Backstepping is a recursive method for stabilizing the origin of a system in strict-feedback form. It's an important technique in nonlinear control theory.

## How It Works

In each step, the smallest "unstabilized" single-step strict-feedback system is isolated. Feedback is used to convert the system into a single-integrator system. The resulting single-integrator system is stabilized.(no content)The single-step procedure can be completed iteratively to stabilize an entire strict-feedback system.

## Applications

Backstepping is one of several techniques that normally take advantage of results based on Lyapunov's theory for control of nonlinear systems.(no content)Petar V. Kokotovic, a professor at the University of California, Santa Barbara, has made significant contributions to nonlinear control, especially the backstepping stabilization method.

## Practical Advantage

A practical way to understand backstepping is that "rather than having to design a controller for a 100th order system, one might use backstepping to show that all one really needs to do is find a controller for a 2nd order system and then use backstepping to extend that controller to the 98th other orders."

Web search results for query: "Tracking control"

Links: [{"title":"Control track - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_track"},{"title":"Mail Isolation Control and Tracking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mail_Isolation_Control_and_Tracking"},{"title":"Video tape tracking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Video_tape_tracking"},{"title":"Antenna tracking system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Antenna_tracking_system"},{"title":"Satellite Control Network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Satellite_Control_Network"},{"title":"Fire-control radar - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fire-control_radar"},{"title":"Time and attendance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time_and_attendance"},{"title":"Fleet management software - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fleet_management_software"},{"title":"Fixed assets management - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fixed_assets_management"},{"title":"Traction control system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Traction_control_system"}]

The search results show several different types of "tracking control" systems across various fields:

## Video Tape Tracking Control
In a video tape recorder, tracking is a calibration adjustment which ensures that the spinning playback head is properly aligned with the helical scan signal written onto the tape.(no content)The control track is used to fine-tune the tape speed during playback, so that the high speed rotating heads remained exactly on their helical tracks rather than somewhere between two adjacent tracks.

## Traction Control System
A traction control system (TCS), is typically a secondary function of the electronic stability control (ESC) on production motor vehicles, designed to prevent loss of traction (i.e., wheelspin) of the driven road wheels.

## Antenna Tracking System
An antenna tracking system tracks a primary antenna to follow a moving signal source, such as a communication satellite.

## Fire-Control Radar
A fire-control radar (FCR) is a radar that is designed specifically to provide information (mainly target azimuth, elevation, range and range rate) to a fire-control system in order to direct weapons such that they hit a target.

## Satellite Control Network
The Satellite Control Network (SCN), operated by the United States Space Force's Space Delta 6, provides support for the operation, control, and maintenance of a variety of United States Department of Defense and some non-DoD satellites. This involves continual execution of Telemetry, Tracking, and Commanding (TT&C) operations.

The term "tracking control" appears in multiple technical and operational contexts, each with its own specific purpose and application.

Links: [{"title":"Decentralised system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Decentralised_system"},{"title":"Decentralization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Decentralization"},{"title":"Bitcoin - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bitcoin"},{"title":"Stochastic control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stochastic_control"},{"title":"Scalable Urban Traffic Control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scalable_Urban_Traffic_Control"},{"title":"Voltage control and reactive power management - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Voltage_control_and_reactive_power_management"},{"title":"Truly Nolen - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Truly_Nolen"},{"title":"Mission command - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mission_command"},{"title":"Witsenhausen's counterexample - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Witsenhausen's_counterexample"},{"title":"Control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory?amp="}]

Based on the web search results, here's what I found about decentralized control:

## Overview

Decentralization is the process by which the activities of an organization, particularly those related to planning and decision-making, are distributed or delegated away from a central, authoritative location or group and given to smaller factions within it.(no content)Concepts of decentralization have been applied to group dynamics and management science in private businesses and organizations, political science, law and public administration, technology, economics and money.

## Systems Theory Definition

A decentralised system in systems theory is a system in which lower level components operate on local information to accomplish global goals.(no content)The global pattern of behaviour is an emergent property of dynamical mechanisms that act upon local components, such as indirect communication, rather than the result of a central ordering influence of a centralised system.

## Benefits and Applications

When the system is controlled by multiple controllers, the problem is one of decentralized control, which is helpful in many ways, for instance, it helps control systems to operate over a larger geographical area.(no content)Decentralization facilitates scalability by allowing the incremental addition of controlled intersections over time with little change to the existing adaptive network, and it also reduces the possibility of a centralized computational bottleneck and avoids a single point of failure in the system.

## Examples

Real-world examples include insect colonies where control is distributed among homogeneous biological agents who act upon local information, and without any form of central control, these insect colonies achieve global goals by performing required tasks.

Links: [{"title":"Distributed control system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_control_system"},{"title":"Distributed version control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_version_control"},{"title":"Distributed Access Control System - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_Access_Control_System"},{"title":"Category:Software using distributed version control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Software_using_distributed_version_control"},{"title":"Distributed concurrency control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_concurrency_control"},{"title":"Talk:Distributed control system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Distributed_control_system"},{"title":"SCADA - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SCADA"},{"title":"GitHub - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GitHub"},{"title":"Coronado Productions - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coronado_Productions"},{"title":"Multi-room audio - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Whole_House_Audio"}]

## Search Results for "Distributed Control"

The search returned information about several different types of distributed control systems:

### Distributed Control System (DCS)

A distributed control system (DCS) is a computerized control system for a process or plant usually with many control loops, in which autonomous controllers are distributed throughout the system, but there is no central operator supervisory control.(no content)The key attribute of a DCS is its reliability due to the distribution of the control processing around nodes in the system, which mitigates a single processor failure—if a processor fails, it will only affect one section of the plant process, as opposed to a failure of a central computer which would affect the whole process.(no content)Distributed control systems (DCS) are dedicated systems used in manufacturing processes that are continuous or batch-oriented.

### Other Types of Distributed Control

The search also revealed several other meanings:

- **Distributed Version Control**: In software development, distributed version control is a form of version control in which the complete codebase, including its full history, is mirrored on every developer's computer.

- **Distributed Access Control System**: Distributed Access Control System (DACS) is a light-weight single sign-on and attribute-based access control system for web servers and server-based software.

- **Distributed Concurrency Control**: Distributed concurrency control is the concurrency control of a system distributed over a computer network; in database systems and transaction processing, it refers primarily to the concurrency control of a distributed database.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Links: [{"title":"Consensus (computer science) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus_(computer_science)"},{"title":"Chandra–Toueg consensus algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chandra–Toueg_consensus_algorithm"},{"title":"Raft (algorithm) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Raft_(algorithm)"},{"title":"Paxos (computer science) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paxos_(computer_science)"},{"title":"Consensus clustering - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus_clustering"},{"title":"Algorand - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Algorand_(cryptocurrency_platform)"},{"title":"Proof of work - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Proof_of_work"},{"title":"Shapiro–Senapathy algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shapiro_Senapathy_algorithm"},{"title":"File:Raft Consensus Algorithm Mascot on transparent background.svg - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Raft_Consensus_Algorithm_Mascot_on_transparent_background.svg"},{"title":"Computational phylogenetics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computational_phylogenetics"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about consensus algorithms:

## Overview

The consensus problem requires agreement among a number of processes (or agents) on a single data value.(no content)A fundamental problem in distributed computing and multi-agent systems is to achieve overall system reliability in the presence of a number of faulty processes, which often requires coordinating processes to reach consensus, or agree on some data value that is needed during computation.

## Applications

Example applications of consensus include agreeing on what transactions to commit to a database in which order, state machine replication, and atomic broadcasts.(no content)Real-world applications often requiring consensus include cloud computing, clock synchronization, PageRank, opinion formation, smart power grids, state estimation, control of UAVs (and multiple robots/agents in general), load balancing, blockchain, and others.

## Key Algorithms

The Paxos consensus algorithm by Leslie Lamport, and variants of it such as Raft, are used pervasively in widely deployed distributed and cloud computing systems. 

**Raft:** Raft is a consensus algorithm designed as an alternative to the Paxos family of algorithms. It was meant to be more understandable than Paxos by means of separation of logic, but it is also formally proven safe and offers some additional features.

**Paxos:** Paxos is usually used where durability is required (for example, to replicate a file or a database), in which the amount of durable state could be large. The protocol attempts to make progress even during periods when some bounded number of replicas are unresponsive.

The consensus problem requires agreement among a number of processes (or agents) on a single data value.(no content)A fundamental problem in distributed computing and multi-agent systems is to achieve overall system reliability in the presence of a number of faulty processes, which often requires coordinating processes to reach consensus, or agree on some data value that is needed during computation.

## Applications

Example applications of consensus include agreeing on what transactions to commit to a database in which order, state machine replication, and atomic broadcasts.(no content)Real-world applications often requiring consensus include cloud computing, clock synchronization, PageRank, opinion formation, smart power grids, state estimation, control of UAVs (and multiple robots/agents in general), load balancing, blockchain, and others.

## Key Algorithms

The Paxos consensus algorithm by Leslie Lamport, and variants of it such as Raft, are used pervasively in widely deployed distributed and cloud computing systems. 

**Raft:** Raft is a consensus algorithm designed as an alternative to the Paxos family of algorithms. It was meant to be more understandable than Paxos by means of separation of logic, but it is also formally proven safe and offers some additional features.

**Paxos:** Paxos is usually used where durability is required (for example, to replicate a file or a database), in which the amount of durable state could be large. The protocol attempts to make progress even during periods when some bounded number of replicas are unresponsive.

Based on the web search results, here's what I found about parameter estimation:

## Overview

Parameter estimation is a branch of statistics that deals with estimating the values of parameters based on measured empirical data that has a random component.(no content)The parameters describe an underlying physical setting in such a way that their value affects the distribution of the measured data.

## Common Methods

Several estimation techniques are widely used:

1. **Maximum Likelihood Estimation (MLE)**: Maximum likelihood estimation is a method of estimating the parameters of an assumed probability distribution, given some observed data, achieved by maximizing a likelihood function so that the observed data is most probable.

2. **Method of Moments**: The method of moments is a method of estimation of population parameters that starts by expressing the population moments as functions of the parameters of interest, sets those expressions equal to the sample moments, and then solves those equations for the parameters of interest.

3. **Minimum Chi-Square Estimation**: In minimum chi-square estimation, one finds the values of parameters that make the test statistic as small as possible.

## Applications

For example, in radar the aim is to find the range of objects by analyzing the two-way transit timing of received echoes of transmitted pulses, where the reflected pulses are unavoidably embedded in electrical noise.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [completed] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [completed] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.
